title: New York Home of Socialite, Style Icon Lee Radziwill Sells for $4.25M
text:
The New York City apartment of socialite Lee Radziwill, the sister of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, has sold for $4.25 million, according to closing documents filed with the city on Monday.



The three-bedroom home spans the entire 15th floor of a 1920s stone co-op in Manhattan’s Lenox Hill neighborhood. It hit the market earlier this year, asking $5.7 million, following Radziwill’s death in February at the age of 85.



More: Billionaire Cliff Asness to List Trophy Miami Penthouse for $29.5M

Born into New York “aristocracy” like her sister, Radziwill lived a colorful life mostly in the public eye. She became a princess in her own right after marrying her second husband, Polish nobleman Prince Stanislaw Albrecht Radziwill, in 1959, after which her fame rose further as the sister-in-law of President John F. Kennedy.



Her apartment, with hardwood floors, built-in bookshelves and extensive crown molding, was everything one would expect from an exclusive pre-war co-op building. The home enjoys its own elevator vestibule and the privacy of being the only unit on the floor, according to the listing with Mary Rutherfurd and Leslie Coleman, both of agency Brown Harris Stevens.



The master bedroom Brown Harris Stevens

A voluminous living room boasts a wood-burning fireplace and ample sunlight through a triptych of arched windows overlooking East 72nd Street, images of the home show.



Public records show executors of Radziwill’s estate officially closed on the apartment the same day that Christie’s auctioned off about $1.27 million worth of the socialite’s possessions, including jewelry, fine art and furniture. Among the biggest sales from that night was a rare photographic record of her and Jackie Kennedy’s visit to India during her sister’s role as first lady.



The auction also included much of the furniture from the Upper East Side apartment, including Radziwill’s pink-and-mint-striped bedroom suite, which sold for $4,750, including the buyer’s premium—as well as porcelain dinner sets and books from her private collection.

Radziwill was a style icon who surrounded herself with celebrities and literati of the day, including writer Truman Capote, the Rolling Stones and Andy Warhol.



The buyer, a business executive, and his wife, according to property records, could not immediately be reached for comment.



The listing agents declined to comment on the sale
